list.item: Jacob Omnium. 1st dress—Morning jacket, black body coat, light waistcoat, and brown trousers.
Herbert Manifest. Black frock coat, trousers and waistcoat.
Grimsby. Blue (rather old fashioned) coat, grey waistcoat, and trousers; small gaiters.
Harriet Pointer. Handsome muslin dress, bonnet, and lace mantle.
Mrs. Pointer. Handsome silk dress, bonnet, and shawl.
Charlotte Manifest. Blue-striped silk dress, bonnet, and lace mantle.
Warner. Cotton gown, brown holland apron, bonnet, cotton handkerchief over her shoulders.

div.stage: Scene I. — A Room in Mrs. Pointer's House, moderately furnished.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pointer.
sp.p: (going to the table)No letter! that's very odd; I saw the postman coming down the street. (rings bell)Enter Warner, R. 1 E. Well!

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: Well, mum!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Hasn't the postman been here?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I don't know, mum.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You don't know? Then, who is to know?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: That's what I was thinking, mum, as I'm the only servant you keep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: I've a great mind not to keep you.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Very good, mum; then, if you please, this day month—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, I won't allow you to finish the sentence.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: (aside)I knew that, or I shouldn't have begun it. (postman's knock)

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: There he is, fetch the letter. Warner crosses—Exit, L. 1 E. I don't understand what Mr. Omnium means by not having sooner answered my note of yesterday evening.Re-enter Warner with two letters; she is reading the directions as she comes in, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, that is funny.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: What is funny, pray?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Why, mum, here's one letter from Mr. Omnium and one—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: No servant of mine ever took such liberties as you do; you have been with me too long, Warner.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Very likely, mum; then, if you please, this day month—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Give me the letters and leave the room. Warner gives letters and exit; Mrs. Pointer looks at one letter. Enter Harriet, who passes behind and peeps over her shoulder, R. 1 E. Who is this from I wonder?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I know whose writing it is, ma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: So do I, miss; I won't even condescend to read it.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Shall I condescend, ma?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: No. (opening second letter) This is from Mr. Omnium.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I don't care about his letters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You don't, Miss Pointer? You don't care about the letters of your future husband?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Well, ma, if he is to be my husband, I dare say I shall have plenty of letters from him some day or other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Harriet, you provoke me by your indifference; look at Mr. Omnium's money and then look at your own: but you can't look at your own, for you have got none to look at.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I've got a little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Unless you marry with my consent, not one penny.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You don't imagine I should marry without it? (aside) Knowing that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Very proper indeed! (looks at first letter) What audacity!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Will Mr. Omnium go out with us to-day?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Of course: at least I haven't read his note, but of course he will. (reads) Why, would you believe it, he actually says he can't?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Well, ma, why shouldn't he? Do you know, I really do not think he has any wish to marry me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: What does that signify? if I choose it he shall: moreover, he shall go with us to-day.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I don't think he will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Won't he? (rings) I am not very fond of allowing people to say either can't or won't to me, my dear. Enter Warner, R. 1 E. Warner, put your things on this instant, and go—

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: I shall expect a month's wages, mum—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Hold your tongue! I shall want you to take a note over the way to Mr. Omnium.

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: Yes, mum!Exit, R.(knock at the door)

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: There's somebody calling: I won't be at home; you go to your room, put your things on, and be ready to go—(crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: I shall expect a month's wages, ma!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Don't be silly! Exit Harriet, R. He can't go out with us—can't he?Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: There he is, fast asleep over his favourite book, “Hints on Matrimony.” What chapter? (taking up book) I'll be hanged if I didn't think so!—“On Mothers-in-law.” (calling him) Sir!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (speaking in his sleep)A nice little wife!—how charming!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (louder)Sir—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: But, no mother-in-law—no—no—mother-in law—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (bawling)Sir—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (struggling and waking)I will not be tyrannised over in this way—(jumps up) I tell you, madam,— once for all—(runs against Grimsby) Ah! Grimsby,—is that you?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes, sir; but I'm not madam.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I suppose I was dreaming

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You frightened me I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Frighten a soldier?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I'm not a soldier now; when I was I argued in this way—Her Majesty pays me—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: None of your everlasting arguments, they make my head ache.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Perhaps they do, but, they lost a capital soldier, when they turned me out of the army for arguing. No man ever obeyed orders better when I was once convinced they were right.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Soldiers and servants should do as they're told and ask no questions.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Very likely, but what is any order worth if it won't bear argument?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Go!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: There it is again, that's an order: but if I obey it and go, how are you to know why I came?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Confound you, why did you come then?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: To tell you that a friend of yours called just now.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Why didn't you shew him up?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: He couldn't stop, he had just come up from the country and was obliged to go a little further, but he'll soon be back, and hopes you won't leave home till he has seen you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Don't know!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Didn't you ask him?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I've been told to open the street door, and I did it—I've been told I'm to ask no questions, and I didn't. (aside) Had him there I think!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: The same rules don't apply in every case.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Now, sir, don't that show the necessity of argument?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Good gracious, no! Had he any one with him?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes, a young lady: and a very nice looking one I should say, but of course that admits of argument.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: It's Herbert Manifest I shouldn't wonder, I wish it may be, I really do want a friend's advice.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You're above asking mine, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Well, old Grimsby, to do you justice, I believe your advice would be honest.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: And I know it would, and that don't admit of argument.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'm glad there's something that doesn't. Grimsby, I'm uneasy and uncomfortable.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I've seen that for some time.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: But, you don't know the cause?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes, I do: you don't know whether to get married or not, and you feel bothered!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (aside)A-hem! (aloud) Grimsby, were you ever married?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Excuse me, sir, that's my secret.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Do you think I ought to marry?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes, if you like it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Do you think I should do right to marry Miss Pointer?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Do you see any objection to her?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: To any of her family, then? (going closer to him) I don't mind what I say to you—I mean—(looking timidly round) —her step-mother?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Dear me! don't you think she is, if anything, a little positive?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: And rather domineering?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: And yet you see no objection to her?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No! but you aren't the man to tackle that lady, you haven't half nerve enough: bless you, her domineering would be all bosh if you wouldn't stand it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'm afraid if I were once married that she would take the management of the whole house.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: What house?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Mine to be sure.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Why, you never would think of making a mother-in-law part of your establishment surely?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: She would insist upon it.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Would she? then, sir, my advice can be of no further use to you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: But I choose you to give it me: hang it, I will have my own way with somebody.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Quite right, sir, but you had better begin with Mrs. Pointer.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I have. She wanted me to escort them to several places to day, and I have sent a note to say I can't.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: She'll make you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Will she? you don't know what I am when I am once roused. (outer bell rings, L.)Exit Grimsby, L.(nervously) I hope that's not a note from her—but why should I care if it is? what I have said I'll do—I'll do! and what I have said I won't do—nothing on earth shall make me do—if I can possibly help it! (throws himself on sofa)Re-enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: A young woman, sir, with a note from Mrs. Pointer.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (with an air of indifference)Let her come in.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Come in, my dear.Enter Warner, L. 1 E., with letter.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Your dear, Mr. Grimsby?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: A nice young woman is all the world's dear.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Mr. Grimsby—there's manners in all situations.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Is the young person there?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Brought a note from Mrs. Pointer, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Give it to my man.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: No sir, can't give it to anybody but you—them's missus's orders. (crosses to C.)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R.)Very well. (she gives it to him, he reads it)

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (L., aside to her)Are you as positive as your missus?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: (C., aside to him)No reflectiveness, Mr. Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Give my compliments to your mistress and tell her—

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: I must trouble you to write it sir, them's missus's orders.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Very well, wait outside and I'll write.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Hadn't I better—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Mrs. Warner, them's master's orders. (Warner crosses to L.)Exit Warner, followed by Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (reads)“My dear Mr. Omnium,—what can you mean, you ungallant creature, by ‘can't come’? you must be joking, we shall expect you at one.” (rising) shall you? (goes to table, writes and reads out) “My dear Mrs. Pointer,—I was perfectly serious; I am equally serious in the expression of my regret—and remain yours very faithfully, Jacob Omnium.” She can't take offence at that, and I hope she won't, for though firm as a rock, I don't like these battles. (rings)Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E. Give that—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (taking letter)Ah!Exit, L. 1 E.Omnium walks up and down—Re-enter Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Grimsby, what did you mean by “Ah?”

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I was thinking of your firmness, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Nonsense; firmness—if I had not written, I should have got that poor girl into a scrape.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You may as well put your coat on, sir—you'll have to go!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: No such thing! (ring at outer bell)

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: There's your marching orders, sir.Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'll not give way one inch!Re-enter Grimsby, followed by Warner, with letter, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Here she is again, sir, with another note.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: (giving note)You're to answer this directly, sir, missus says!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Whether I like it or not?

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Well, sir, I suppose she meant, “if you please” —but she didn't say so!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (to Grimsby)Let the young woman sit down. (as Warner passes Grimsby he chucks her under the chin)

sp.speaker: Warn.
sp.p: Mr. Grimsby, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Nothing particular—it's a way we have in the army.Exeunt Warner and Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (reading)“My dear Mr. Omnium,—You must and shall give us the pleasure of your company; you can't have any engagement of consequence; and, if you have, put it off;—Harriet is quite hurt at your inattention,— your's very sincerely.” I don't believe Miss Harriet is a bit hurt, she seems to me a very reasonable young woman; I never knew her shew any undue anxiety for my company. (goes to writing table) Now Mrs. P., we'll see who can get the best of it for once. (writes and reads) “My dear Mrs. Pointer,—You must allow me to be the best judge of my own affairs; I positively have an engagement, and I positively cannot put it off,—Your's very sincerely.” (rings) That's a settler. Enter Grimsby, L. Give this and come back.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes sir!Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes, the lady has got her answer this time, and I feel pleased at my own firmness. Re-enter Grimsby, L. 1 E. Grimsby, I'm an altered man. (outer bell rings) What in the world is that?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Only the door bell, sir. (aside) The altered man is frightened by a ring at the bell.Exit.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes, either I'll not marry at all, or if I do I'll be master in my own house. (going) I feel at this moment perfectly cool—perfectly collected, and prepared if necessary, to encounter—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (meeting him at the door)Mrs. Pointer, sir!(Omnium darts back to the opposite side)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: How very unlucky! (Grimsby round to R.)Enter Mrs. Pointer and Harriet, L. 1 E.(embarrassed) Good morning, Mrs. Pointer: good morning, Miss Harriet!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (C., playfully)Why, you lazy creature, it's almost one o'clock, and you have got your house jacket on.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R.)Really, Mrs. Pointer, I think I may be allowed to regulate my own dress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: In the house—yes: but you can't expect Harriet and me to go out with you in that costume?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't expect it—I'm not going out: surely you got my note?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Mamma, if Mr. Omnium does not wish it—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (angrily and aside to Harriet)Harriet (aloud) Yes, I got your note—but what of that? When a gentleman wishes one thing and two ladies wish another.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Indeed, I don't wish him to go with us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (angrily and aside to Harriet)Harriet! (aside to Omnium) You see how that dear creature gives way to you in everything. (aloud) As I was saying—when a gentleman wishes one thing and a lady wishes another— the gentleman must naturally give way.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I cannot give away, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (coaxingly)Yes, you can; Grimsby fetch your dear master's coat.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: No, no, upon my word—besides, I can't put it on here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (to Grimsby)Do as I desire you, if you please.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (aside)Master won't speak, so I suppose I must do it.Exit, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You don't know what an honour I have in store for you, Harriet shall help you on with your coat.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Mamma, I'd rather not.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Quite correct, Miss Harriet, I couldn't think of allowing it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Then I'll do it myself, come, off with it. (she takes hold first of one sleeve and then of the other, and pulls off his jacket, and gets round to R.)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (C.)I declare I never saw anything like it, there's no earthly use in saying no to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (R.)Not a bit, bless you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Miss Harriet, I'm quite ashamed.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: (L.)Oh, Mr. Omnium, I know what mamma is.Enter Grimsby with coat, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p:
Dear me, what is there to be ashamed of? Fiddle-de-dee, Mr. Omnium. (to Grimsby) Here, give me the coat. (she takes it—to Omnium) Now, right arm first, isn't it? There. (putting it on him) Then the left, that's
it. Now, you look something like a gentleman who is going out with his friends.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: But hear me, Mrs. Pointer—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (to Grimsby)Where's his hat?Exit Grimsby, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: You must hear me, I expect a friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: What friend can you have who regards you as I do? Enter Grimsby with hat and gloves, R. 1. E. Here's your hat. (takes it and puts it on his head) And there are your gloves. (gives them) Now, come away at once, for we want to go to three or four exhibitions. Harriet, my dear, take Mr. Omnium's arm.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: He doesn't wish it, mamma; it would only annoy him.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Annoy me? (crosses) Oh, I can't allow you to say that. (offers his arm)

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You have another for me I trust?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Oh, yes, ma'am. (she takes his arm; as they are going off, he stops) Mrs. Pointer, one word—I'm very happy to go with you—very happy, indeed; but you will let me off after the first exhibition, won't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: We'll see about that by and bye.Exeunt, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: He's regularly taken prisoner and marched off between a file of female cossacks; the enemy will never consent to exchange him, and his only chance is to make his escape. (outer bell rings) There's somebody else, and as master is carried off, I had better stop and do the honours. Enter Herbert and Charlotte Manifest, L. 1 E. I beg your pardon, sir; if I'd known it was you, I'd have come to the door myself.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Never mind; your master is out they tell me.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: He's only just gone, sir? I wonder you didn't meet him.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Will he soon return?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Well, sir, that's rather uncertain; he's my master —but just now, I don't think he's exactly his own.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (C.)Ah! how so?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (R.)Why, he's gone out with two ladies, sir— and, saving your presence miss, ladies generally like to have their own way.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (L.)And quite right, when they can get it.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: There's one of them two, miss, that always gets it.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And who may she be?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Who she may be, miss, admits of argument—I only hope, she never will be, what, I take it, she wishes to be.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How very mysterious—what is her name?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Your curiosity is very natural, miss, but I'm not sure I'm at liberty to mention it.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I'm glad my friend Jacob has such a discreet servant; did you give him my message?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes sir, but you forgot to give me your name.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Herbert Manifest.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Well, sir, he guessed it was you, and he wants to see you above all things.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: That's the reason he is gone out.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You musn't be angry sir; he couldn't help himself, he couldn't indeed.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: What should I be angry about? I'm come to stay some days with your master. (taking out his purse) Here, you'll find a cab at the door, just get our things out and give the man this. (gives money)

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I shouldn't wonder if he was to say his fare is more, sir.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: And I should wonder if he didn't say so; but he won't have it, get the things out, give him the money, and shut the door in his face.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (aside)This gentleman has some firmness about him, he'll do master good.Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (L.)What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R.)What can it signify to you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I like to have all mysteries cleared up, and Mr. Omnium was so very kind to me when he staid with us in the country, that I have always felt a great interest about him.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Why you were a mere child?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
Perhaps that made me feel his kindness the more;
at all events I have a more pleasing recollection of him than of any one else I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Well, we shall hear all about it bye-and-bye when he comes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How are we to amuse ourselves in the meantime?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Oh! anyhow; here's a book I shall read. (takes book and sits at R. table)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How like a man! (crosses to R.) I shall poke about and see what sort of a place he has got.Exit to inner room, R. D.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: How like a woman! What's this? “Hints on matrimony.” Why, Jacob, are you travelling on my road?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (coming to door)Herbert, do come here! such charming pictures! just the thing you like.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Well, dear, I'll come. (puts down book and goes to his sister, R. D.)Enter Omnium hastily, and looking anxiously behind him, L. E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Safe at home once more and free from pursuit for an hour or two. There's some advantage even in crowded rooms, We were separated and the thought struck me to make the most of the accident that restored me to liberty, and fly. Ye powers! what a woman is that Mrs. Pointer; when she's angry I'm frightened, and when she's civil I'm always afraid she's just going to be angry. Oh! Gordon Cumming, undaunted conqueror of fearful animals, did you ever encounter a mother-in-law! I doubt it, you couldn't have been alive to tell the story; why should I subject myself to such tyranny? I will not, I will be a man, so, let her come, let her enter the room this moment, let her say, coaxingly, (as she can) “Mr. Omnium, won't you return?” I should answer in the same tone, “No!” sharply. “Mr. Omnium, I desire you'll return.” “No.” peremptorily. “Mr. Omnium, I insist on your returning!” “No, madam, no, my eyes are opened, the spell is broken, reason is restored, Richard is himself again!”Enter Herbert and Charlotte—they look at him and at each other in astonishment, R. D.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Why Jacob! is that you?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (terrified)Ah! who's that?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (going to him)Who should it be but Herbert Manifest.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (confused)My dear old friend, I'm delighted to see you!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: What has excited you so?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'm not ex—ci—ted!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Oh, but you were; what on earth did you mean by “Richard's himself again?”

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Nothing; I did not know anybody was so near me, and I was trying over something I heard at the play the other night; you must know I fancy myself a bit of an actor.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Was that all?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'm truly glad to see you again; and how is my little darling Charlotte?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Let her answer for herself (leads her forward)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How do you do, Mr. Omnium? (crosses to C.)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (L.)You don't mean to say you are my little darling; I mean—why, la! how you are altered, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (C.)Don't you mean to shake hands with me?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I shall only be too happy—how do you do, Miss Charlotte? (shaking hands)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Why not Charlotte, without the Miss, as it used to be? What is there to be alarmed at in me?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Nothing; but I don't know how it is, I begin to suspect I must be of rather a nervous temperament.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R.)Only just discovered that, Jacob.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: What, have you observed it before?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Rather.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (to Charlotte) And you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well, I suppose I was too young to judge; I only remember that nobody was half so kind to me as you—that nobody took me such nice walks, or such jolly donkey rides.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Ah, you remember them, do you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: And how I used to lead the way, when there was an awkward bit of road?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Yes; and sometimes followed to whack the animals when they were lazy.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: So I did.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nay, more—I remember how I often got a cut intended for the poor donkey.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Dear me, was I so awkward? I hope I didn't hurt you!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: If you did, it's five years ago; besides you used to call me your little wife, and I have since been told that in this highly civilized country of ours, men are allowed by law to beat their wives, to a certain extent.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Oh, shocking! but tell me, Herbert, what has brought you to town so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Two things—one concerns Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Don't, Herbert.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Why not? anything concerning my little wife must interest me.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: It's nothing very important—but there is a rich man with whom it's of consequence to me to keep well, who persecutes her with an offer of marriage, and so I thought it best to bring her away for a little while.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then she doesn't like him, poor dear?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: You're a good fellow, as I always thought you: I'd do anything rather than she should have him.— I'd sooner marry her myself, fifty times.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (curtseying)I can't be grateful enough, for the sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: No, no, my dear Miss—I mean Charlotte—you know what I mean (to Herbert); and now your second reason.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Well, that concerns myself—and I stand in need of your best advice.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: It's not a love affair?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: And you are really in love?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Deeply—desperately.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I envy you—I wish I were in love.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: With her?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't know who she is; I mean with anybody—with somebody.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You don't seem to be very particular!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I am; but why, I say, I wish I were in love, is, because I can't help being afraid I shall somehow or other, get married without.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nobody can make you marry unless you choose it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I should like to be quite sure of that. (to Herbert) Is she pretty?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: As an angel! My dear Jacob, she has a pair of eyes!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'm glad of that, because they once wanted me to marry a young woman who had only one!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Pshaw! her hands—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Have love at their fingers' ends, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: They have, indeed; and her feet—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Suppose we stop there;—Is your passion returned?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (to Charlotte)Then what has he to fear?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: A mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
Herb.
sp.p: What would you advise me to do?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Why, go to her house; hold yourself as upright a dart; walk right up to her; look her straight in the face, and say—Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.(Together)

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Mrs. Pointer(Together)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Mrs. Pointer! (rushes to opposite side, and turns away his head)(Together)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Mrs. Pointer! (turns up the stage and pretends to be looking at something)(Together)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Mrs. Pointer! Herbert! (follows, and joins her brother, R. table)Enter Mrs. Pointer, followed by Harriet, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L.C.)Upon my word, this is most extraordinary conduct, Mr. Omnium!—is there anything so very terrible in the bare announcement of my name, that it should cause not only you, but all your friends to turn their backs upon us?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
(R.)I assure you, ma'am, if I did turn my back,
it was quite an involuntary proceeding; and as to my friends, they could have no motive—(fetching Charlotte, R. C.) Allow me to present to you my dear young friend, Miss Charlotte Manifest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: What you mean, Mr. Omnium, by this additional insult is best known to yourself; but what I mean is this—I have not the slightest wish to improve my acquaintance with that young lady.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R.)Insult, Mrs. Pointer? You must allow me to say that—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (advancing, C.)Stay, Jacob, this is my affair. Whatever opinion, madam, you may have formed of me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L. C.)One moment, sir, if you please. (to her step-daughter) Harriet, my dear, return home this instant I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, ma. (going, lingers up L.)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I was going to say, madam, that whatever opinion you may have formed of me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: And I was going to say, sir, that whatever opinion I may have formed of you, as you seem to be with your particular friend, I had probably better not express it. I shall take it as a favour if you will address your conversation to anybody in the room rather than to me.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Madam, I shall endeavour to oblige you.Crosses behind, shakes hands, and exit in conversation with Harriet, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (advancing to Omnium)As for you, sir, your conduct requires explanation—much explanation: I came hither to seek it, but you are not alone; I shall therefore write to you. (going)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I think that much the best way, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Do you? I'm not so sure. On second thoughts I'll speak to you at once.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (aside)I doubt that.Runs off, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Yes, I'll speak now, this instant. As she turns to do so, Herbert re-enters behind her, L. 1 E. Gone?—this is positively insulting!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I'm sure, madam, Mr. Omnium—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p:
You're extremely kind, Miss What-d'ye-call-'em,
but Mr. Omnium will have to explain for himself. As, however, he has thought proper to leave the room, it affords me a good opportunity for a final explanation with your brother.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside)Does it?Runs off, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (turning)I am utterly at a loss to understand, Mr. Manifest—gone!—this is evidently a pre-concerted plan! But he don't escape that way; a message by his sister will do quite as well.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (aside)Will it?Runs off, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (turning)I must trouble you, Miss Manifest— she gone too!—insolent creature! But I'll be revenged!Exit, L. 1 E.

div.stage: Scene I.—Room as before in Omnium's House. Omnium seated on one side in deep thought—Herbert in the same state on the other; Charlotte on an ottoman in centre, working.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (C., after a pause during which she looks first at one and then at the other)Well, gentlemen, when you have quite come out of your brown study, I shall be happy to hear what you have to say.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (L., aside)There's something odd and he must explain it.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R., aside)I must get it out of him somehow.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No answer? (gets up and goes to Omnium) Mr. Omnium, you wished to speak to me.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: A thousand pardons—presently if you please.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (crossing to Herbert)Herbert, you had something to tell me?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, but not now—not now!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Very well, I shall take my work into the next room, and leave you to entertain one another.Exit, R.

div.stage: (after a short pause Omnium and Herbert look at each other, both seem about to speak, but only cough and turn away again)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Herbert!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Well, Jacob?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Your sister has left the room.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I know it: but that is not what you were going to say?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Not exactly.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Say it then?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: So I will. It struck me that Mrs. Pointer's manner to you was very strange.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Ditto me, with regard to her manner to you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes, but I know her.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: So do I.(they rise and come forward)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (L.)The deuce you do! And pray, sir, do you know her daughter also?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside, R.)So eager, I must be cautious. (aloud) Slightly.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: What do you think of her?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I shouldn't exactly like to say.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (aside)Dear me, he has formed a bad opinion of her.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I should like to know what you think of her?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I think more about her step-mother than about her.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Is it possible? then, my dear Jacob, accept advice which is thoroughly disinterested,—let nothing on earth induce you to marry Mrs. Pointer.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: You need not alarm yourself, my thoughts run in a very different direction.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside)Then I have no cause for uneasiness. (aloud) Jacob, you contemplate marriage?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I own it!—I am rich, and I think it's time I lived for somebody else besides myself.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I applaud your sentiment: you know my friendship, confide in me?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I will; but you have a love affair, confide in me first?Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: We are interrupted.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Grimsby, leave the room!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: There's a reason why I shouldn't.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I've got a letter for you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Give it then! (Grimsby gives it) Now leave the room!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Now there's no reason why I shouldn'tExit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (looking at the letter—aside)So, she has put her threat into execution. (puts the letter in his pocket—to Herbert aloud) Go on!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Nay, read your letter.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I had rather not.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Well, you are the coldest lover I ever knew.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't know that I'm a lover at all; but there's no question of love here—this is from the mother.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: And you're afraid of her?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Afraid of her! my dear friend, did you ever happen to see a laughing hyena?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Once.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then there she is again, eyes—teeth—claws and all, yet I must say, like her prototype, always looking grand, and occasionally even pleasant.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Why ally yourself with such people?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Well, I was introduced and called—the mother was very civil, so I called again: one day a walk was proposed, this led to another and another—in short, I'm a creature of habit, and I became quite a house-dog there. I said nothing particular and I meant nothing particular, and yet I begin to be afraid—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: That you are fairly hooked in?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't know what to say to it; and now comes this letter which I don't half like to open—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Out with it, and let us know the worst. (Omnium fumbles at his pocket) Out with it, I tell you! (Omnium draws it slowly out) Here, give it me!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
No, hang it, I'll read it myself. (opens letter and reads out) “Mr. Omnium—Your attentions to my step-daughter have become the subject of general remark. I cannot suppose that you mean to trifle with her feelings, but understand distinctly that I don't mean to allow you. As you hesitate to put the question to her, I shall put a very direct one to you—do you mean to marry my daughter, or do you not? If you answer ‘yes,’ I am ready
to welcome you with all the tenderness of a mother-in-law, if ‘no,’ I'll pursue you through every court of law in the kingdom.”

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Egad, she's a trimmer!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Isn't she? (reads) “Postscript—I am almost sorry I have written that last sentence, because you're a dear good creature, and will I am sure act as becomes you.”

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Capital! Signed?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: No, I won't tell you that.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Never mind, I shall know in time. What do you mean to answer, “yes” or “no?”

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes. (after a pause) Or no—I can't settle which

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I can't sufficiently admire your decision.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Now don't quiz me; it's impossible to make up one's mind in a moment. Suppose you leave me to myself a little bit and join your sister. I'll soon write an answer;—I have more firmness than you think.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (going)If you have, Jacob, remember that this is the time to exercise it.Exit, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
(walking up and down)Now, Jacob, whatever you do, be calm but be decided. Stay! suppose I just write, and ask for twenty-four hours' delay?—No I won't —anything is better than suspense. Why not send a bold refusal at once? I'm not to be bullied into marrying!— as to her threats about law, I have plenty of money to pay if that's all, and as to wives, there are plenty of them to be had; such a nice dear girl as Charlotte Manifest perhaps—if I dared think of her—with a hundred attractions, and no mother-in-law—no mother-in-law! I won't hesitate another instant. (sits down to write) “Madam— the peremptory nature of your letter leaves no time for consideration. I have every respect for Miss Pointer, and I hope and believe that I feel as I ought about you,”—she may make what she likes out of that—“but there is also a respect due to myself, and thus driven into a corner, I feel it my duty, with all becoming expression of regret, to write the painful monosyllable ‘No.’—Your obedient servant, Jacob Omnium.” (folds and addresses the note) “To Mrs. Pointer.” There, that's settled, once and for ever—there's no retracting now, and I shall force my friend Herbert to admit that I have such a thing as
firmness. (rises) I don't feel quite sure that I have done right, now; it is terrible to be hurried so—what shall I do? Ah! I have it, chance shall decide—chance has been my friend all my life, and it often decides better for us than we can for ourselves. Marriage is said to be a lottery, and a lottery I'll make of it,—I'll write another letter to say “yes,” and draw lots for which I shall send. (returns to table and writes) “Madam,—Your letter seems to assure me of success with your charming step-daughter, though I have never ventured to make any proposal; pray assure Miss Pointer of my devotion, and believe that my opinion of you remains unchanged. In obedience to your wish, I have only to add the otherwise superfluous monosyllable, ‘yes,’ and remain, your's most faithfully, Jacob Omnium.” (folds and addresses the letter) “To Mrs. Pointer.” (rings bell, rises, takes both letters, holds them behind him, and comes forward)Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.(turns his back to the audience, and while speaking keeps shuffling them) Come here, directly.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: The young woman is waiting for an answer, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Tell her to wait.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: That's quite unnecessary, sir; she has been doing so this half hour.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Don't argue—fetch my hat.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Are you going out, sir?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Why, sir, you don't usually have your hat to walk about the room.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Fetch—my—hat. Exit Grimsby, R. 1 E. Now, fortune, befriend me— Enter Grimsby, with hat, R. 1 E. and make that stupid ass, old Grimsby, do right for once.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
Give me that. (he takes the hat, puts in the letters, and shakes them up) Now, sir, mind what I tell you, and don't laugh—you are laughing. Shut your eyes—no, open them. You'll play some trick—I won't
trust you; (gives him the hat) hold this. (takes a silk handkerchief out of his pocket) Stoop your head down.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Your hat isn't big enough for me, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Silence! (ties handkerchief round his head)

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Going to make a Cupid of me, master?(Grimsby kneels down)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Fortune; not Cupid—stupid;—how many fingers do I hold up?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Five—ten—four—two.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That will do; hold up your head, and plunge in your hand.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: In the hat, to be sure—be quick, I want to know my fate.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Fate! la, sir, you frighten me; I hope it's all right.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: In with your hand, and draw out one of those two letters. (he does so) give me the hat. (takes the hat puts it down, and unties the handkerchief) what have you got?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: A letter, directed to Mrs. Pointer.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Give it to her servant. (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (aside)Oh! what is he after?Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That's what I call decision; but I should like to know what the decision is; I've a great mind to break the seal,—no, I must be firm, I'll burn it. (lights match, and is about to set fire to it)Enter Herbert and Charlotte, R. D.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (C.)Jacob, what are you about?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Only going to burn a letter.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (R.)A love-letter, I dare say.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (L.)Upon my honour, I don't know whether it is or not.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Now, I'm sure it is.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then you are better informed than I am; Herbert knows half the story, and you may both hear the rest,—I am about—or, rather, I suddenly, found myself about to marry a—a—yes—a charming young person; but she's not so charming as you, Miss Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Hush, hush! you mustn't talk about me.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
(sighing)Ah! when I received a letter from
my—I must say, self-elected mother-in-law—(a spasmodic sigh) Ah!—calling upon me in a sort of pistol-to-head manner, for an instant yes or no—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: At that pistol's point I left you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: At first, I thought I would say no.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: First thoughts are always best.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (aside)What a little darling she is. (aloud) Then I thought I would say yes.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I prefer second thoughts.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Well, I wrote a decided no!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And you were quite right?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes: but you see on reflection—not that I want firmness—I feared I might, though unintentionally, have compromised the young lady, so I wrote a decided yes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And which did you send?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Neither!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Mr. Omnium! (together)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Jacob! (together)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't mean that; I have sent one, but I don't know which.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: You really must explain?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That is soon done:—chance placed me in my present position, and I resolved that chance should take me out of it—I put the two letters into a hat, blindfolded old Grimsby, made him draw one, sent him off with it: and that I may not even know which I have sent, I'm going to burn the other.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: This is quite a new kind of firmness: but don't burn the letter?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: If I keep it, firm as I am, I shall open it.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Give it to me then?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No, give it to me, I won't look at it?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't like to expose you to temptation, they do say all ladies are curious.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Not about what does not interest them.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (sighing)Ah, and this being about me, of course does not?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I prove the contrary by trying to save you from temptation.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Take it dear, miss Charlotte, take it? (gives her the letter)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I'll bet sixpence you have said yes!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Seek not to shake my firmness, or influence my destiny by a vile bet? I hope it's no—oh yes, it must be no—oh no, I fear it's yes. Fortune, smile upon me, and save me from such a mother-in-law as Mrs. Pointer?

sp.speaker: Herb., Char.
sp.p: (together)Mrs. Pointer?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Herbert, this astonishment—this agitation!— a horrible suspicion flashes across my brain—we love, that is I don't—but you do, the same individual!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: It is too true!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Does she return your passion?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Ardently.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Forget that the name accidentally escaped me.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then is your friend the most wretched of mortals; what have I done? my brain's on fire—my pulse is at 150—I must have air: Herbert, farewell, and if ever you see me again it will be under very different circumstances.Rushes out, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: What is he going to do? I'll follow him, I must know what he means.Rushes after him.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: So, they are rivals, and the “yes” or “no” was about Harriet: he doesn't care about her I'm certain, or he would have said yes in a moment, at least I would. How can I assist my poor brother? by looking at this letter? (drawing it half out) but no, I promised, and I won't break my word, even to serve him. (returns it)Re-enter Herbert, L. 2 E. Well, Herbert?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I can't find which way he's gone; I thought to seek Mrs. Pointer's, but then I thought she would refuse to see me. There's no time to lose—his letter may destroy my hopes for ever, I'll write myself—one last and desperate attempt.(he sits down and writes a letter)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
(aside)Poor Herbert, I wish I could help him: and I know I should be serving his friend too, for I'm sure he's more frightened than pleased at his prospects; what is the use of a woman's wit if she can't hit upon
some plan at such a moment as this? Ah, it's come, it's a risk, but it must be tried. (takes out letter and holds it in her right hand behind her back) Have you written it?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Yes! (folds, seals, and directs it)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (going to him)Give it to me and I'll send it? (she takes his letter with her left hand and puts it in her pocket, then brings her right hand forward) Ring the bell. (Herbert rings)Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E. Will you be so kind to take this letter directly?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Certainly, miss. (aside) Her majesty is losing a lot of penny stamps to-day.Exit, L. 1 E.Re-enter Omnium, out of breath, L. D.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R.)What in the world became of you, I tried to overtake you, but failed?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't wonder at it, I had a plan—and I ran like a madman; but it struck me all on a sudden that it wouldn't answer—so I ran back again. Miss Charlotte, one question—have, you looked at that letter?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (C.)Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (L.)I'm sorry for it, I was in hopes that female curiosity would have prevailed—however, open it now, I must know the contents.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: It will be better for us all to know the worst, open, Charlotte, open?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (aside)What in the world am I to do, I haven't got it, I'm regularly caught?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: If you hesitate, give it to me?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No, rather to my brother, you would be too much agitated.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (aside)Too much agitated!—what delicate forethought! That girl's a treasure.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (giving letter)Here, Herbert, read. (aside) Mind what you're about—invent something.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R., aside, and in astonishment)Invent! what?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Read word for word; don't spare me; I am anxious, but I am firm.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside, and looking at letter)My own letter! (aside to Charlotte) What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (aside to him)Can't you guess? I sent his, instead of yours.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside to her)Then, Mrs. Pointer has got both his letters.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (aside to him)Hush!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Go on, go on,—I have said “yes,” no doubt, I feel I have.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (confused) I can't read your writing.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I was agitated, and my hand shook.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: No doubt, Charlotte was quite right; you are agitated now, therefore I won't read it; and to prevent the possibility—there—there—there—(tears up the letters)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Hold!—I must know what I have written. (crosses to R. C.)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: You'll know quite time enough, but not one word of this shall you see.Exit, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R.)Herbert! Herbert! (to Charlotte) Can you explain his conduct?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (L.)I had rather not attempt it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: It's such a pity I should stand in his way, when I really don't care about the lady.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nor does she care about you, according to what Herbert said.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't think she does, a bit.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Then what made you say yes?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Her mother; that is, if I have said it; but that is what I want to know.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Then her mother will make you marry her, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I'm afraid she will; she obeys that stepmother in everything.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Then she must be a very good girl.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes; but she is not so pretty as you are.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Oh, you must not talk about me.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Do let me—and to you; I'm rather a nervous person—and your voice is so soothing.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Miss Pointer has a very nice voice—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Not like yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And beautiful eyes—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
Not like yours. (aside) What a dear little wife
she would make—and then, no mother-in-law—that's an enormous advantage!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: And it struck me that she had a very pretty hand.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Not like yours—(taking her hand) oh no, no, not to be compared to yours.Enter Herbert, R. D.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside)Hollo! they seem to be rather close together.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (aside)My brother! what a relief! (walks away, L.)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: So, here you are again!—I was just saying to your sister—I forget what I was saying.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: It doesn't much signify, for, if am not mistaken, there is a missive coming that will claim your undivided attention.Enter Grimsby with letter, which he holds up, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Another billy from Mrs. Pointer—it's written on “immediate.”

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then give it me, and leave the room.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (gives letter—aside as he goes)When physic is marked “to be taken directly” it's generally pretty strong stuff.Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (after ineffectual attempts to open letter)I'm afraid you'll accuse me of want of firmness, but I can't open this letter—read.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I'm a little nervous myself—Charlotte. (Charlotte comes down, C.) Read. (gives her the letter)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: In your hands, good fortune must befal me.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R., aside)Is that old rascal going to make love to the whole sex?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (C.)Gentlemen, steady your nerves, I am about to open the book of fate.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (L., aside)Upon my life, I must sit down. (goes to a chair)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It's signed “Harriet Pointer”—Is that the mother or the daughter?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (looking over her)The mother—the mother.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: You know her writing?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Too well.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Silence in the Court! (reading) “Sir, I am not a little surprised at the determination you have come to”—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then it was no—and she's piqued. (gets up) My dear friends, give me joy—I may marry every woman, that is, any woman I please—but go on. (sits down again, L.)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (reading)“I was prepared to expect no small amount of vacillation”—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That tells the whole story;—vacillation is the very word a woman uses when she's intensely savage —oh, this is charming!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aside to Charlotte)It looks well, doesn't it?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (aside to him)The second letter can't have been delivered.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (aloud)She had better finish.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: By all means—I'm perfectly easy—(gets up) stay—(calling) Grimsby!Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: You brought that letter—there's a sovereign for you.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Thank you, sir. (aside) I'm glad it wasn't prepaid.Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; I can't always control my feelings. (sits down) Now, if you please.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Let me see—vacillation—oh—(reads) “I hope we shall neither of us have cause to regret the choice you have made.”

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Regret it? I'm the happiest man alive—give me music, that I may dance a polka! (a polka is played on an organ outside) there it is, fortune favours me still; (dances round stage and calls out) Grimsby!Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Give those men a shilling, and tell them to go on playing.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Yes, sir! (aside) one pound one,Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (after second turn throwing himself into his seat)Stop that music; I'm out of breath.(organ ceases)

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Perhaps you'll rest then, while I finish the letter

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I thought it was all over.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No, you interrupt me so, where was I? I must go back a little (reads) “I hope we shall neither of us have cause to regret the choice you have made, and I feel confident that Harriet will prove such a wife as will ensure your permanent happiness.”

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (jumping up)What?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: So it is, I assure you.Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I've stopped the music, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (rushing at him)You horrid old villain, give me back that sovereign.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: It's past 4 o'clock, sir, and the Savings Banks are shut.Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (returning to them slowly and despondingly)This is a sad change (puts his hand on Herbert's shoulder)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (R.)Sad indeed!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (L.)Very—very sad.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (C. putting his hand on Charlotte's shoulder, unconsciously, then starting back)I beg your pardon; do you think it sad?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Pardon me, my question was suggested by an indescribable feeling, why so?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It is easily answered, I grieve for my brother who loses by your gain, and for you, who seem to gain nothing by his loss.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Is it not enough?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Yes, but I had ventured to hope that you had some trifling personal feeling in the matter.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It may be, that under other circumstances, I might have had.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
You will think me presumptuous, but you have said too little or too much. Is it possible, that under any circumstances, you could have thought of one, who compared to you, is old—who, compared to you, is ug—spare
me further comparison—who feels, in every respect, his inferiority.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Excuse my saying more, than that, I do not see the inferiority.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Wretched being that I am—one question more?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I cannot allow it—you have crossed me—unintentionally I admit—in the fondest wish of my heart; it consoles me to think that Harriet will have a husband worthy of her, so much for myself—Charlotte must not be worried.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I only wanted to ask her—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I know, kind as you are, still you are not free from the miserable vanity of human nature; on the point of marriage with one girl, you fancy another cares about you, and you cannot rest until your morbid wish to know the truth be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Oh, Herbert!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: It shall be satisfied—it cannot signify—my sister and I shall soon be gone, and of course, we shall never meet again. You were kind to her when a child, and always called her your little wife; she contracted a childish affection for you, and grew up in the cherished notion that you were to be her husband, (you may not have met with such instances in life but I have). This notion, the difference of your ages and other personal matters, on which you have more lightly touched, have not had power to shake, I hope your vanity is satisfied.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: To the full, and yet is my position any thing but an enviable one. I am about to marry one to whom I am indifferent; to injure irreparably the best and dearest friend I have; and to lose the unlooked-for chance of her who would make my happiness for life. One solitary wish is left me—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: And that is?—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That the music would come again, for I want to resume my polka. (begins dancing again)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Jacob, you are very mad.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: No such thing, (to Charlotte) unless it be with joy, (to Herbert) I am a thoroughly altered being, even the first stage of madness has left me; I am no longer nervous, (holding out his arm) feel my pulse, does it flutter?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Steady as a rock.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I should think so; look at me, what is my height?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I should say about five feet seven.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Wrong again, I'm nine feet ten.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I told you you were mad.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Not a bit of it, never mind what a man looks: he is—what he feels: I feel myself nine feet ten—and from the commanding height I enjoy, I shall dictate the future fortunes of those about me.—To begin, you Herbert Manifest, shall marry the object of your affections, Harriet Pointer.

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Impossible! her step-mother will never consent; to it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then you shall run away with her—No you shan't! it's a low vulgar thing to do, and though you might like it at the time, you would soon cease to respect her. Leave Mrs. Pointer to me. (to Charlotte) You, Charlotte Manifest, shall marry—if you will condescend to marry—Jacob Omnium.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My brother has said too much; you know it cannot be—Mrs. Pointer—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Excuse my vulgarity; (snapping his fingers) that for Mrs. Pointer! But supposing all obstacles removed—could you?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well, I think I could.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (kissing her hand)Enough. I'm nine feet ten, without my shoes!Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (crossing and aside to Omnium)Master, you'd better cut;—here's Mrs. and Miss Pointer coming.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Don't whisper to me, sir. Go back; make your announcement.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: (crosses back and turns)Mrs. and Miss Pointer.Enter Mrs. Pointer followed by Harriet, L.— Herbert and Charolotte retire up the stage, R.; Mrs. Pointer having an open letter in each hand, advances and holds them out towards Omnium.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (with careless indifference)My dear Mrs. Pointer, I hope you are remarkably well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Well, sir? How can you—how can I—how can anybody be well, with such proofs of perfidy as I hold in my hand?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R.C.)How very funny!—I see you have received both my letters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L. C.)Funny, sir!—is that the word? Could mortal man conceive—could mortal woman believe in the existence of such treachery?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: My good lady—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: I'm not your good lady, sir;—nothing should induce me to become your good lady!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I recommend you to calm yourself. I never intended to send you both those letters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (aside)Then all may yet be well. (aloud and mildly) Not both?—then which, sir? which?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Well, I was in doubt, and so I drew lots.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (angrily)Lots, Mr. Omnium?—is Miss Pointer to be disposed of by lots? (crosses the stage with an indignant sweep, R.; as she does so Omnium crosses to Harriet, L.)

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (aside to Harriet)Don't mind what I say; I'm acting for you and Herbert as well as myself.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: (aside and shaking hands with him)I understand and thank you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (turning)What! are you disgracing yourself by shaking hands with an individual who draws lots for you?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: (L.)La, ma! why not? Marriage is a lottery; and only think how proud I should have been if I had been drawn a prize.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (R.)I shall never teach you to respect yourself. But my business, sir, is with you: as to my allowing such a man to marry my step-daughter, if you were even to go down on your knees—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (C.)Don't be alarmed, Mrs. P., I'm not going down on my knees.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Don't Mrs. P. me, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: My good woman—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: How dare you call me a good woman?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Gently, Pointer, gently.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Pointer!—you've gone mad, sir!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: On the contrary, I have come to my senses. But to business. You thought I wished to marry Miss Pointer?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Thought, sir? I know it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then you know more than I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Whether you wished it or not, you shall do it.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I tell you I won't; it's not my intention.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Then hear my intention. If there is a court of law—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Stop! there are plenty; but they require a plaintiff as well as a defendant. Now I'll settle your cause for you in a moment: if Miss Pointer will say that it is her wish, I am ready to marry her at a moment's notice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (crossing L., and aside to Harriet)Now we have him. (aloud) Speak, my dear, and freely—you have my full permission.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Oh! thank you, mamma. Then nothing shall induce me to have Mr. Omnium for a husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Come away this instant. (aside to Harriet) We'll have this out when we get home.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Stay, Mrs. Pointer, and for your own sake be reasonable; I should be glad to make this visit pleasant to you:—you wish your step-daughter married?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Naturally.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: She never will be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Then it won't be my fault.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That is what I wished to come to—it will; you have frightened me, and you will frighten others; Miss Pointer deserves a good husband, but she will never get one while you loom in the back ground as a mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L. C.)I shall not stay to be insulted, there are twenty men who would jump at her.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (C.)Now listen!—produce one of those twenty jumping men within an hour from this time, give your consent, and I will increase her small fortune with a cheque for three thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (aside)He's a nasty little fellow, but it won't do to lose that. (aloud) You're very generous I must own, but give me a week?

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
(R. C.)Not an h
our more than I have said.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L. C. aside)What's to be done, I mustn't throw away such a chance? (aloud and in an insinuating tone) Mr. Manifest!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Madam! (coming down, R. C.)(Charlotte goes to Omnium and takes his arm)

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You have professed an affection, which I think you called ardent, for Miss Pointer?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: I professed, madam, what I felt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Oh, I dare say; you must be aware that I could have no personal objection to you? (Herbert bows stiffly) but your prospects were not good, I'm told they have improved?

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: Considerably.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: I'm very glad to hear it: and, as Harriet will now have an addition of three thousand pounds—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: You consent to our marriage?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Well, yes—I think so.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Write it then, or you won't get the money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (angrily)Write you the cheque, I'll make you pay for it at all events.(Mrs. Pointer goes to L. table; Omnium to R. table, both inside; Herbert crosses to Harriet, L.)

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: My dear Harriet!

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Herbert, what unexpected happiness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (standing up and leaning her hands on the table)Harriet, what does all that mean?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You know I never contradict you, mamma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You always told me you didn't care about him?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No, mamma! you told me I didn't, and I never said a word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: And you told me you were attached to this Mr. Omnium?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: No, mamma! you told me I was, and as I said, I never contradicted you.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: That shews how mistaken you have been.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: I shall be obliged to you not to interfere in my family affairs.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R., holding up the cheque)Further than—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L. C.)Exactly. (coming forward and handing the writing) Mr. Manifest, there is my consent.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (coming forward)And, Herbert, my dear fellow, there is the cheque.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Harriet, take the cheque.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: (L.)I can't, mamma, without my beloved husband's leave!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Bless me—so you're in love with him, are you?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, mamma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Then you have deceived me all this time?

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: Yes, mamma.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (C., to Omnium, savagely)You'll have no wife at all events!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: (R.)I beg your pardon, madam—I am to have that honour!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You, child? I am sorry for you, unless indeed you have one, who in her responsible capacity of mother-in-law—

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Now don't let us revert to unpleasant topics —she hasn't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Then she's to be pitied; and when you see how our house is managed—

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: (L. C.)Our house! My dear Mrs. Pointer, you don't suppose we shall quarter ourselves upon you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: No—but I shall live with you, of course, and give you the full benefit of my experience in managing all your affairs!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: My dear madam, the sooner we understand one another the better; we shall be happy to receive you at all reasonable times, but my house will never have but one master and one mistress!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Then I withdraw my consent!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: You can't;—I presume that was my friend Jacob's reason for causing you to give it in writing.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (R. C.)Charming!

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: (L. C.)Is it? And you think I'm sorry—you're mistaken; I prefer Mr. Manifest to you, infinitely—oh, infinitely; there's nothing I admire in a man like decision.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Then you ought to admire me, for I'm sure I was decided enough, when I said I wouldn't be your son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You were; and, for the moment, I felt a sort of respect for your character,—allow me to hope you're better, Mr. Omnium!

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: I don't know—but allow me to rejoice that you are in better hands than mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: Be good enough to ring for my maid, sir. (Omnium rings bell on R. table)Enter Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Mrs. Pointer's maidExit Grimsby, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Harriet.
sp.p: You're not going to leave me, mamma, at such a moment?

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: It's high time I went, when everybody is rude!

sp.speaker: Herb.
sp.p: For myself, Mrs. Pointer! I disclaim all intention of rudeness; I mean to be master in my own house, and I said so—in all else you will find me anxious to consult your wishes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: That gentleman never said half so much to me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I'm sure, ma'am, this gentleman and his wife will be happy to shew all due respect to the kind protectress of their sister-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: The world is not so bad as I thought; everybody, except Mr. Omnium, has grown suddenly civil.Enter Grimsby and Warner, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Grimsby, we're all going to be married—now is the time for your secret.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You shall have it, sir.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Were you ever married?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: No, sir; and what's more, I'll take care I never will be.

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: What's that, Mr. Grimsby—then pray what becomes of your engagement to me?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I'm sure I never asked you.

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: You have chucked me under the chin at least twenty times, and I consider that equivocal.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: If it's equivocal it admits of argument.

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: I got hold of the wrong word—I meant equivalent.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p:
Equivocal or equivalent, England is at this moment peculiarly jealous of the honour and character of
her soldiers—marry the young woman and I'll give her a hundred pounds for a portion.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: That doesn't admit of argument. Mrs. Warner, I am yours, name the day.

sp.speaker: Warner.
sp.p: Very well, then if you please, this day month—

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: You can't forget your old habits.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: (to Mrs. Pointer)The fates have decreed that we shall not be relations, but let us shake hands, perhaps we shall be all the better friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. P.
sp.p: I've no particular objection, but I never can approve of your letting chance decide in so important a matter as marriage.

sp.speaker: Omnium.
sp.p: Can't you, Mrs. P.?—then I must appeal to those whose kind approbation can, in a moment, change that chance into a certainty. Please to sanction our Marriage Lottery—and as you confer happiness on us, so may all happiness be yours, when the turn comes to you.
